PatientMatching.TEXT:
Record date: 2090-10-09
NAME: Usrey, John
MRN: 6762675
This is a 76-year-old man who comes in with a chief complaint of left calf pain.
This occurs after walking about one block and pain is sufficient to prevent him
from walking further. He will then stop, pain will disappear. He will continue
walking at which time it will occur at about the same distance. There is no rest
pain. The pain had been present for a couple of months although it has been
increasing in severity.
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Is significant for intracranial bleed secondary to an
AV malformation. He refused surgery at that time at Campellton-Graceville Hospital and has done
well on Dilantin without any seizures. There has been no further bleed or problem
from this malformation. He also has treated hypothyroidism. He is status post
TURP, cholecystectomy, and appendectomy. He does have a chronic anxiety
disorder for which he is on Ativan intermittently. He also has pustular psoriasis.
MEDICATIONS: Dilantin 600 mg per day, which keeps his level at about 7. At
these levels he has had no seizures. He is also on Synthroid at 0.075 per day.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: He is a mostly German-speaking man. There is a
right-sided tremor which has been present since his intracranial bleed. Neck
supple. Blood pressure is at 140/80. Weight 184. Heart rate is at 70. There are
no carotid bruits. Lungs are clear. Heart is regular without gallop or murmur.
Abdominal exam - No mass, tenderness, or organomegaly. There are multiple
scars. There is a bruit over the right femoral artery with a decreased pulsation there
compared to the left. There is no pulse palpable below popliteal on the right side.
There is no visible ischemic change of the right leg. The left femoral is fuller, and
there is a palpable dorsalis pedis on that side.
IMPRESSION: Peripheral vascular disease, probably right iliofemoral. He will
undergo arteriovascular studies. He will also be placed on aspirin at 81 mg per
day. In addition he is begun on Lipitor 10 mg per day for hyperlipidemia. He will
follow up following that vascular study. This evaluation was also communicated to
her daughter, Quinn, because of the language barrier.
Xenia Jaramillo, M.D.
XJ/camp/williams
**************************************************************************************************** Record date: 2090-12-13
Pt. of Dr. Jaramillo presents for initial visit as new PCP. He is currently being evaluated for R leg claudication. He reports having pain inhis R leg after walking for one block -- he rests for a few minutes and then it goes away. He denies pain in his left leg. No CP or SOB.
PROBLEMS
Hypothyroidism
Seizure disorder controlled with dilantin-related to AVM -- occurred 9-10 yrs ago
Noncongenital arteriovenous malformation left temporal AVM
Hyperlipidemia
Peripheral vascular disease
Osteoporosis
PSH:
Cholecystectomy in 2060's
Appendectomy 50 yrs ago
ALLERGY
NKDA
MEDICATIONS
LEVOXYL (LEVOTHYROXINE SODIUM) 75MCG 1 Tablet(s) PO QD
DILANTIN (PHENYTOIN) 100MG 1 Capsule(s) PO TID
LIPITOR (ATORVASTATIN) 10MG 1 Tablet(s) PO QHS 30 day(s)
FOSAMAX (ALENDRONATE) 70MG 1 Tablet(s) PO QWEEK 30 day(s)
SH: Smoked 2ppd x 35 yrs and stopped 15 yrs ago; occ wine with dinner; worked before as a securities investment broker; lives with wife and daughter
ROS: As per HPI; denies GI or GU complaints; reports having a rectal done at his last PE with Dr. Jaramillo; rest of ROS unremarkable.
VS: 125/75 88
PE: General -- alert; no acute distress
Neck -- no bruits; no JVD
Lungs -- CTA bilaterally
CV -- RRR; nml s1s2
Abd -- soft
Rectal -- refused; said Dr. Jaramillo did in 10/90
Ext -- L DP 1+ with good LLE cap refill; no RLE DP pulse palpable
11/12/90 LE studies
Test today demonstrates A-I disease (worse on the right), right SFA occlusion and right distal popliteal/tibial vesssel disease. On the right, patient is fairly well collateralized across the ankl level at rest and poorly after 4.5 minutes of exercise. On the left, patient is well collateralized across the ankle level at rest and after 4.5 minutes of exercise.
10/17/90 TSH and chem 7 WNL; Dilantin level stable
A/P: 76 yo male hx seizure d/o s/p ICH, hypothyroidism, hyperlipidemia, PVD presents for general f/u. Found to have RLE arterial disease.
1. PV -- will refer to Dr. Uddin for further eval. Not on ASA due to hx ICH -- will ask his Neurologist Dr. Acuna if trental OK before starting
2. Hyperlipidemia -- check fasting lipids and LFTs this week; continue current Lipitor dose
3. Endo -- continue current Synthroid dose
4. Neuro -- pt's level has always been in this range, so won't change at this time
5. HCM -- continue Fosamax; will pursue GI studies in future visits
RTC 2-3 months
______________________________________________
Debra A. Rosenberg, M.D.
**************************************************************************************************** Record date: 2091-07-04
NAME: Usrey, John
MRN: 6762675
Patient presents for follow-up visit after long hospitalization. He went in to have an
AAA repair and suffered a postop MI. He was in CCU for 3-4 weeks at which time
he sustained a Pseudomonas pneumonia, small bowel obstruction, and PE. He
subsequently had his CABG done at the end of April and was discharged at the end
of May to Grant Clinic. He did well at Grant Clinic and was discharged
from there on the 10th of June, and he presents to me for follow-up today.
He states that he feels well. He denies any chest pain or trouble breathing since
discharge. He does not remember anything from his hospitalization otherwise. He is
mentally intact. He reports that he has not had a bowel movement for 3 days and had
some pain a couple of days ago. He is passing gas, last done yesterday. No dysuria.
His daughter reports that he is eating well, that he is at his baseline mental status,
that he has had not had any acute complaints at home.
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: As per HPI. Also, hypothyroidism, seizure disorder
due to a congenital AVM, osteoporosis, peripheral vascular disease.
ALLERGIES: No known drug allergies.
CURRENT MEDICATIONS: Aspirin 325 q.d., atenolol 25 b.i.d., Zocor 20 q.h.s.,
Carafate 1 gm p.o. b.i.d., Celexa 10 q.d., multivitamins, thiamine 100 q.d., Seroquel
37.5 q.h.s. and 12.5 q.a.m., Flomax 0.8 q.d., Synthroid 100 q.d., Dilantin 150 p.o. t.i.d.,
Colace 100 t.i.d.
VITAL SIGNS: Blood pressure 112/52. Pulse 72. Weight 162.
PHYSICAL EXAM: General - Elderly male in no acute distress. Appears well in
consideration of his recent long hospitalization. Neck - No JVD or bruits noted
bilaterally. Lungs - Clear to auscultation bilaterally with no wheezes or rales. CV -
RRR. Normal S1, S2. No murmurs. Abdomen - Positive bowel sounds heard in all 4
quadrants, although mildly decreased. Soft, mildly distended. No masses. No HSM.
No fluid wave. Extremities - He has 1+ firm pitting edema to his mid-shin.
LABS: From June 13, 2091, show CBC with white count of 4.4, hemoglobin 11.2,
hematocrit 32.2. Chem 7 - BUN 26, creatinine 0.7, glucose 203, Dilantin 5.6.
ASSESSMENT & PLAN: 76-year-old male, history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia,
coronary artery disease, peripheral vascular disease, status post CABG in April as
well as AAA repair returns after an extended hospitalization with complications of
pneumonia, SBO, and PE who comes in for follow-up visit. Despite everything,
patient looks well.
(1) CV. Will continue cardiac medications at this time. Will likely change Zocor
back to Lipitor but will check his labs first. Patient would benefit from cardiac
rehab at this time. He is scheduled to see Dr. Nutter at the end of this
month. Will arrange for him to have regular cardiac care after this. He has
seen Dr. Quesnel for his postop CABG issues.
(2) PVD. Patient status post AAA repair. He has seen Dr. Uddin and is doing
well.
(3) Neuro. Patient on Dilantin 150 t.i.d. as per Dr. Acuna. It would be okay to
decrease him to 100 t.i.d. as he was before. Will check his levels today but
likely decrease to 100 t.i.d. Will refer back to Dr. Acuna for follow-up.
(4) Endocrine. Will check TSH. Likely will continue current Levoxyl dose.
(5) Osteoporosis. Okay to restart Fosamax.
(6) GI. Patient with constipation. He can start Citrucel or Metamucil twice a day.
Can also use Dulcolax daily until he has a bowel movement and then decrease
to every other day as needed. Can also adjust fiber therapy as needed.
Instructed patient and daughter that if patient is passing gas, it is okay.
However, if he stops, they should call immediately.
(7) Psych. They should continue Celexa and Seroquel for now. Will review charts
from Grant Clinic to see why medications were started and will likely
taper him off them.
In general, need to review records from Grant Clinic in order to see what
happened there. Will consider that in my recommendations for his further care.
Return to clinic in 2 weeks.
Debra A. Rosenberg, M.D.
DAR/camp/quevedo
**************************************************************************************************** Record date: 2091-10-27
Pt. presents with his daughter for a f/u visit. He states that he has been feeling well. He has been going to cardiac rehab, and has been increasing his exercise regimen. He denies CP/SOB. He has been eating well and his having regular BM. No difficulty urinating.
He and his daughter report that he has been more quick tempered recently. He will get very angry and upset with his wife and it is creating great stress at home. When asked about it he states that he does not know why it is happening. However he says that he would never become violent.
Problems
Hypothyroidism
Seizure disorder : controlled with dilantin-related to AVM
Noncongenital arteriovenous malformation : left temporal AVM
Hyperlipidemia
Peripheral vascular disease
Osteoporosis
Allergies
NKDA
Medications
Dilantin (PHENYTOIN) 100MG, 1 Capsule(s) PO TID
Lipitor (ATORVASTATIN) 10MG, 1 Tablet(s) PO QHS x 30 day(s)
Asa (ACETYLSALICYLIC Acid) 325MG, 1 Tablet(s) PO QD
ATENOLOL 25MG, 1 Tablet(s) PO BID
Flomax (TAMSULOSIN) 0.8, 1 Capsule(s) PO QD
Seroquel (QUETIAPINE) 37.5MG, 1 Tablet(s) PO QHS
Thiamine Hcl 100MG, 1 Tablet(s) PO QD
Colace (DOCUSATE Sodium) 100MG, 1 Capsule(s) PO TID
Seroquel (QUETIAPINE) 25MG, 0.5 Tablet(s) PO QAM
MULTIVITAMINS 1 CAPSULE PO QD
Levoxyl (LEVOTHYROXINE Sodium) 75MCG, 1 Tablet(s) PO QD
Lasix (FUROSEMIDE) 20MG, 0.5 Tablet(s) PO QD
Folate (FOLIC Acid) 1MG, 1 Tablet(s) PO QD
FeSO4 325 QD
Vital signs: blood pressure 135/70; pulse 76; weight 167
Physical Exam:
General -- Alert; in no acute distress.
Lungs -- Clear to auscultation bilaterally; no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi; good air movement
CV -- Regular rate and rhythm; normal S1 S2; no murmurs, rubs, or gallops
10/24/91 Labs:
Dilantin 2.4
LFTs within normal limits
CBC with hemoglobin 12.5 and hematocrit 36.9
A/P: 77 year old male with history of hypertension, hypothyroidism, hyperlipidemia, status post CABG in March 2091 who presents for follow-up. Increased agitation noted at home.
1. Cardiovascular -- Patient has appointment with Dr. Quesenberry in December 2091 to establish regular cardiology care. His blood pressure is under acceptable control will continue all his current cardiac medications at this time. He is on an aspirin, statin, beta-blocker and folate.
2. Psych -- Patient is on the dose of Seroquel that he was on when he was discharged from GC. He was also on Celexa 10 mg per day, however, I had d/c'd this a few months ago in an attempt to simplify his medication regimen. Will restart Celexa 10 milligrams po QD to help with his anxiety and agitation.
3. Neuro -- Patient's Dilantin has always been subtherapeutic. He is asymptomatic. Will continue to follow clinically for now on his standing dose of medication.
4. Endocrine -- Continue current dose of Levoxyl.
5. GU -- Continue current dose of Flomax.
6. GI -- Will hold patients Colace for now. Instructed him and his daughter to restart the Colace if he should become constituted. Told him to drink a lot of water.
7. Nutrition -- Patient has normal appetite know so will stop his thiamine. Will continue multivitamin.
Return to clinic as scheduled in five weeks to follow up on his Celexa.
____________________________
Debra A. Rosenberg, M.D.
This was typed with voice recogntion technology. Please excuse any transcription errors. -- DAR
**************************************************************************************************** Record date: 2098-10-25
Internal Medicine Admission Note
PATIENT: John Usry
MRN: 6762675
DATE: 10/24/98
TIME: 19:00
PCP: Dr. Xena Acuna
ATTENDING PHYSICIAN: Dr. Quinton Quintela
HCP/FAMILY CONTACT:
CHIEF COMPLAINT: “I came to the hospital b/c I have pneumonia”
HPI: This is a 84M with CAD s/p 4V CABG in 2091 who presents via transfer from Waverly urgent care after a chest xray showed pneumonia. The patient first presented to Waverly on 10/22 with complains of weakness, fatigue, decreased appetite and bilateral shoulder pain for a few weeks. He denied dyspnea, chest pain or pressure, productive cough, sore throat or runny nose. He was noted to have a fever of 101.2 at Waverly but denied other subjective fevers. His daughter had recently been hospitalized with pneumonia but he has no other sick contacts. At Waverly labs were drawn, a chest xray was done and he was given motrin and Tylenol and sent home. He returned for follow up the next day feeling no better. His labs reviewed a leukocytosis and acute kidney injury and his chest xray showed a RLL pneumonia. He was sent to the CGH for further evaluation.
On presentation to the ED at 1pm on 10/23, his VS were 98.2, 87, 122/60, 97% on 2LNC. He got 500cc of NS, Levaquin 750mg PO x 2, Ceftriaxone 1gm IV x 2 doses, his home doses of dilantin, finasteride and plavix and sent to the floor.
Upon arrival to the floor he was in no distress. In addition to the above, he denied recent vomiting, diarrhea or feelings of numbness or dizziness. He has had less appetite recently. He denied injury or trauma to his shoulder which he said had been bothering him more and more for the past 3 weeks.
REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: As per HPI. Other systems reviewed were negative in detail.
PAST MEDICAL/SURGICAL HISTORY
status post TURP :
Hypothyroidism
Seizure disorder related to AVM.
Noncongenital left temporal AVM
Hyperlipidemia
Peripheral vascular disease
Osteoporosis
AAA s/p repair in 3/91;
CAD s/p 4 vessel CABG : 4/91
PE during hospitalization in 3/91
Anemia (iron deficient) : FOBT positive,
Diabetes : type 2- diet controlled
MGUS, stable : per Dr Rhodes 5/97 –
Second degree heart block
RECENT DIAGNOSTIC STUDIES
RH Cath (3/97) DIAGNOSTIC CONCLUSIONS/OVERALL SUMMARY:
1. Right heart catheterization - normal filling pressures. Hemodynamics: RAP
1, RV 25/2, PAP 25/6, PCWP 6, CO 5.73
2. RV biopsy was performed using a shor sheath through right internal jugular
vein approach.
3. A total of 4 biopsy obtained, fixed in formalin and sent to pathology.
Closing RAP 2.
Nuclear Stress 12/96 CONCLUSION
The ECG is negative for ischemia. The sensitivity of
adenosine-induced ST segment changes for detecting CAD is limited.
LV contractile function is normal.
The perfusion iamges show a large area of mild ischemia involving
the anteroseptal and inferior walls
TTE: 11/96. EF 60%, mild/mod MR and inferior wall motion abnormalities.
MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION (source of information)
Asa (ACETYLSALICYLIC ACID) 325MG daily
Claritin (LORATADINE) 10 MG daily
Colace (DOCUSATE SODIUM) 100MG CAPSULE PO TID
Dilantin (PHENYTOIN) 100MG CAPSULE PO TID
Finasteride (BPH) 5 MG PO qhs
Flomax (TAMSULOSIN) 0.8 MG PO QD
Flunisolide NASAL 0.025% 2 SPRAY NAS BID
Levoxyl 88MCG TABLET PO QD (extra pill Sundays)
Multivitamins 1 CAPSULE PO QD #30
Norvasc (AMLODIPINE) 2.5 MG) PO QD
Remeron (MIRTAZAPINE) 15 MG PO QHS x 30 days, at bedtime
Tng 0.4 MG (NITROGLYCERIN 1/150 (0.4 MG)) 1 TAB SL x 3 prn
Zocor 20MG TABLET PO QHS
ALLERGIES/ADVERSE REACTIONS: NKDA
SOCIAL HISTORY: Lives at home with wife. Retired from aon plc. Past tobacco history but quit 30 yrs ago. Denied EtOH. Sick contacts as described above. No pets at home.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
VITALS: 97.6, 95, 160/72, 18, 97%2LNC
General – NAD, lying in bed
Skin – without rash
HEENT – NC/AT, EOMI, no oral lesions, JVD flat
Lymph nodes – no anterior cervical or supraclavicular nodes
Pulmonary – course ronchi right base, no egophany, no tactile fremitus
Cardiac – rrr s1/s2 no m/g/r
Abdomen – soft, nt, nd +bs, no organomegaly, well healed midline scar
Extremity – no edema. 1+DP bilaterally, no clubbing. No shoulder tenderness to palpation bilaterally. Full ROM
Neurology – cn 2-12 intact and symmetric. Strength 5/5 upper and lower extremities bilaterally. Sensation symmetric bilaterally.

RADIOLOGICAL STUDIES
Chest Xray: Airspace opacity in the right lower lobe compatible with acute pneumonia. Small right pleural effusion.
Shoulder Xray: No evidence of acute displaced fracture, dislocation or bone
destruction.
EKG: NSR @89. slight LAD. Normal intervals. Left atrial enlargement. Incr RBBB (seen in V1) No ST segment changes. ?Q waves in III and aVF. ECG on 10/22 shows Mobitz II Heart block.
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 84M with CAD s/p CABG presents with malaise, fatigue and shoulder pain x 3 weeks, found to have RLL pneumonia on chest xray. He has been stable since coming to the floor.
ISSUE #1: CAP: Likely organisms include pneumococus, atypical infections such as h. influenzae, mycoplasma or legionella. Viral causes are also possible. As is superinfection with an organism like Staph aureus if he has influenza.
- Levaquin 750 QOD x 7 total doses
- Will check blood cultures, sputum culture, legionella urinary antigen
- Will rule out for influenza and keep on droplet precautions
- Titrate O2 sats for >96 %
ISSUE #2: AKI: Likely prerenal azotemia as has improved with IVF given in ED.
- C/w IV hydration with normal saline
- Will pursue workup if creatinine remains elevated.
ISSUE #3: CAD: No complaints of coronary symptoms, ECG shows known Mobitz II. Will optimize medical regiment. BNP elevated but no other symptoms of volume overload.
- C/w statin, aspirin
- Aim for SBP < 130 in this diabetic with CAD. C/w norvasc.
- Will add captopril 6.25 TID and titrate to goal given diabetic with proteinuria
- Per old PCP notes, patient is not a candidate for b-blocker. Will f/u this issue with PCP.
- Will recheck AM BNP and hold all IVF.
- Monitor on tele
ISSUE #4: Diabetes: Medically managed at home. F/s AC+HS with RISS. Diabetic Diet.
ISSUE #5: Seizure disorder: c/w dilantin. Will check level.
FEN: Diabetic diet.
PROPHYLAXIS
GI: none
DVT: fragmin/teds
BOWEL: colace
CODE: full
Ordean Quintal, MD
Medical Resident
Pager #22148
